Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Situation2: They greet a few customers politely while scanning items at a quiet store.
Story: I glanced at the clock above the register, my heart thumping a little faster. The family gathering was circled in red on my calendar at home, a promise I’d made to my daughter and grandkids weeks ago. They’d been looking forward to it—homemade cookies, stories, laughter. But here I was, in my cashier’s apron, scanning groceries and greeting the few customers who trickled in with a practiced smile. My manager had called in sick, and I was asked to cover the shift. Each beep of the scanner reminded me of the time slipping away, of the little faces waiting for me. I tried to focus on the customers, offering friendly words, but my mind kept drifting to my family. I felt torn, the weight of responsibility pressing from both sides—my family’s hope for togetherness, my duty to keep the store running smoothly. I could feel the tension building inside me, unsure which role I could let down less.
